Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: New Optical Frontiers for 4D Computational Imaging Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Imaging is a core technology that feeds into intelligent sensing and reasoning about the world. This project advances the frontiers of imaging by supporting development of a broad, new space of "4D lens" designs with fundamentally superior performance. The research team develops technologies to record and process richer data about light flowing through the lens, enabling computational enhancement over the optical image quality. The research team also redesigns the lens itself, lowering the optical requirements and pushing to unprecedented performance in figures of merit such as brightness, size, weight, zoom and cost. This project extends the frontier of what is possible in diverse imaging applications, including 3D imaging, photography, scientific imaging, projection, lithography, and headsets for virtual and augmented reality, microscopy, security and defense.

This research develops the theory, algorithms and tools for designing and optimizing the described 4D lenses. The enabling technical shift is the assumption that the new lenses can be used in the emerging class of computational imaging systems that work with the full 4D light field (set of all rays), rather than simply a 2D image. This project addresses several intellectual challenges theoretically and algorithmically. First, the research establishes a new formulation of the long-standing lens design problem, considering not just 2D optical image quality, but rather the computed image quality after end-to-end 4D imaging and processing. The new formulation significantly increases the complexity of evaluating and optimizing lens designs. Secondly, the research explores and maps the new frontier of lens design space that this approach opens up, to understand its growth characteristics and ultimate limits. The new design approach has potential for fundamental disruption of imaging capability, because it enables lens technology to improve continuously with technology for pixels and processing, which grow exponentially.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project contributes knowledge, methods and case studies in the development of computational imaging systems. One of the core ideas studied in this work is the use of optics that multiplex 4D light (either in the sense of the 4D space of rays in a geometrical optics sense, or in terms of the 4D phase space in a wave optics sense).  These mutiplexing optics often appear like diffusers, such as frosted glass. Such optical multiplexing was studied primarily in the context of encoding light from the world onto a sensor for imaging. Potential benefits were demonstrated that varied by application, and include: imaging 4D light fields in a single shot; system compactness, such as lensless, flat cameras and microscopes; recovery of 3D scene information, such as in volumetric fluorescence microscopy; and ultra-high-speed imaging when coupled with rolling-shutter sensors.  

One of the key findings of this project is that such optically multiplexed sensor data is amentable to scene recovery, but requires the use of modern optimization -based algorithms.  Such algorithms generally require a forward-model computation that predicts sensor values from an estimate of the scene properties, and iteratively tunes the scene estimation to reproduce the real measurements as accurately as possible.  One of the contributions of this project was in the development and evaluation of various forward-models that were sufficiently accurate, efficient enough for iterative optimization, and amenable to real-world calibration.  All of the proposed imaging architectures (hardware and software designs) were prototyped and studied experimentally.  One of the key learnings about the design of multiplexing optics is that randomized, high-contrast optical projections yield superior results.  Randomized optical patterns are more amenable to recovery using processing methods inspired by compressive sensing. Further, an important finding is that high-contrast optical patterns, such as those produced by randomized microlens arrays, yield superior results to non-focusing diffusers.

The knowledge, optical designs and processing algorithms developed were also adapted and applied to computational displays, specifically the design of holographic displays that hold great promise for near-eye applications such as head-mounted displays. In this space, multiplexing optics and optimization algorithms were applied to expand the etendue (specifically the exiting angle) of light from a holographic display. This approach may be applied to increase the field of view and/or the size of the eye-box, and brings holographic near-eye displays a step closer to practical use. 

The broader implications of this project lie in expanding the design space of devices for photography, microscopy, videography, volumetric imaging and displays. Such devices are broadly used in science, engineering and industry, including applications in compact imaging, neuroimaging, high-speed videography, and near-eye displays.
